title: 108_s822
content: The "Child Care Lending Pilot Act of 2003" may be cited as the Short Title. It establishes the Child Care Business Loan Program. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to authorize loans under certain restrictions and limitations. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to authorize loans with specific restrictions and limitations, including the use of proceeds and loans to small, non-profit child care organizations. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to authorize loans for small, non-profit child care businesses, with specific restrictions and limitations on the use of proceeds. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to authorize loans for small, non-profit child care businesses, with restrictions on approved use of funds and eligibility requirements similar to for-profit businesses. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to authorize loans for small, non-profit child care businesses, with restrictions on approved use of funds and eligibility requirements similar to for-profit businesses. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration is required to submit reports on the implementation of the program every 6 months to the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship of the Senate. The program implementation report must be submitted every 6 months to the Senate and House Small Business Committees, detailing program implementation and rule issuance dates. The report on child care small business loans shall include the program implementation date, rules issuance date, and loan application details for the previous 6 months. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report by March 31, 2006. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report on child care small business loans by March 31, 2006 to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business. The report will include program implementation, rules issuance, and loan application details for the previous 6 months. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report on child care small business loans to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business by March 31, 2006. The report will cover the first 2 years of the loan program, evaluating implementation timeliness, effectiveness, and ease of use for Certified Development Companies, lenders, and small businesses. The report on child care small business loans will include details on the implementation of the loan program, participation of Certified Development Companies, lenders, and small businesses, marketing strategies, and the number of child care businesses categorized by status. The report will detail the number of child care small businesses that applied for, were approved for, and received loans under the program, categorized by for-profit or non-profit status and new or expanded businesses. The report will include details on the number of child care small businesses that applied for, were approved for, and received loans under the program, categorized by for-profit or non-profit status and new or expanded businesses. It will also provide information on the businesses in each State, the total amount loaned, and the average loan amount and term. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will issue final rules for the loan program within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by this section will be in effect until September 30, 2006, and will apply to all loans authorized by the Small Business Investment Act.
